chapter.summary: Covers how to assess the needs of adult carers and how to offer information and support with their caring role and wellbeing.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should a carer's needs be assessed?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Offer carers the opportunity to confidentially discuss their own needs as carers (separately from the person they are supporting) and encourage them to recognize their caring role and seek support. Consider asking about:
    • Carer health and wellbeing, for example health concerns, levels of stress.
    • Details of caring, including duration of caring role, time spent caring, type of help the carer provides, and support from family and friends.
    • Support services used.
    • Employment.
    • Concerns, for example regarding caregiving activities, social isolation, financial strain, relationship stress.
  • Make sure carers know about their right to have a carers' assessment: what it is, the benefits of it, and how to obtain one.
    • Consider what further information, advice, and guidance they may need to be fully informed about the needs assessment process and any preparation required (for example arranging for an advocate to help them).
  • Ensure carers know they can still access community support without formal assessment. For more information, see What advice can I give on accessing information and support?

• A carer's assessment provides the opportunity for a person who is an unpaid carer for a family member or friend to discuss their needs with their local authority (separate to the needs of the person they care for). This is a statutory requirement of the Care Act 2014.
  • The carers' assessment should include health, wellbeing, and social care needs and involve a discussion of education, training and employment, and related support.
  • Following the assessment there should be clearly identified outcomes for the carer and they should understand the agreed actions. Information should be shared (as appropriate) with other practitioners and organizations involved with the carer and the person they care for.

[NICE, 2020]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Supporting adult carers [NICE, 2020] and the NHS England publication An integrated approach to identifying and assessing carer health and wellbeing [NHS England, 2016]. The recommendation to make sure carers know about a carers' assessment is also consistent with the NICE guideline Dementia: assessment, management and support for people living with dementia and their carers [NICE, 2018]. Areas to consider asking about in an assessment reflect expert opinion in the review article Assessing and helping carers of older people [Cameron, 2011].

  • Benefits to carers of recognizing their caring role and seeking support include acknowledging the carer's role and contribution, addressing the carer's support needs, and sharing of the carer's knowledge about the person being cared for, which enables practitioners to provide appropriate care and support [NICE, 2020]. 
  • Assessments allow carers to express themselves, be recognized and validated, and feel supported [RCGP, 2014].
  • The primary care team is vital in starting discussions about a carer's support needs and supporting and maintaining their health and wellbeing. Carers' main support needs may be related to their own health or to information and education to support them in providing care. It may be best for healthcare practitioners to address this at the time [NHS England, 2016].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice can I give on accessing information and support?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Make sure carers are aware of their right to information and support and how to access it. Information provision must meet the requirements of the Care Act 2014.
  • Ensure information given to carers:
    • Is up to date and consistent.
    • Is plainly worded, clearly presented, and jargon-free.
    • Is available in a range of formats (for example leaflets, online and digital resources) as well as accessible formats and different languages.
    • Includes discussion and written materials. When providing information, encourage the carer to ask questions.
    • Covers a range of support and advice, including how to access social and community support. 
    • Includes further sources of information and support, for example carer groups and forums.
    • Is relevant to the carer's needs at the time, and helps them plan and prepare. 
    • Is repeated if needed.
  • Give carers information on peer support (carers share experiences, practical advice, and emotional support) and how to access it locally. This might include support groups or online networks and is often provided by volunteers.
  • Organizations and resources providing information and/or support for carers include:
    • Carers First www.carersfirst.org.uk.
    • Carers Trust carers.org.
    • Carers UK www.carersuk.org.
    • GOV.UK website www.gov.uk.
    • Citizens Advice www.citizensadvice.org.uk.
    • Disease-specific organizations.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Supporting adult carers [NICE, 2020] and also reflects information in the Royal College of General Practitioners report Involving and supporting carers and families [RCGP, 2014].

  • Not all carers will require or want a formal statutory carers' assessment, but the NICE guideline committee agreed that it is important to provide information on accessing carer support services if needed [NICE, 2020]. Many carers have little contact with carer services and do not receive formal support in relation to their caring role [DHSC, 2018].

subChapters.fullItemName: Supporting carers in their caring role
subChapters.htmlHeader: How can I support carers in their caring role?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Encourage carers to recognize their caring role and seek support. Discuss the potential benefits for them and the person they care for. For more information, see Why is identifying and supporting carers important?
    • If a carer identifies support needs with information and education to help them fulfil their caring role, address this at the time, if possible. For more information, see What advice can I give on accessing information and support?
    • Investigate ways of offering and promoting services to carers, including through partnership working, for example with carer support services or by nominating carer champions (a designated member of staff who supports and speaks up for carers and acts as a contact for carer information and advice).
  • Involve carers in decision-making and care planning for the person they care for and keep them up to date (with the consent of the person being cared for). This may involve discussing the proposed care plan with the carer and asking for their views and feedback.
  • If discussing with carers information concerning the person they are caring for:
    • Take into account the mental capacity of the person being cared for and their wishes around confidentiality. For more information on mental capacity, see the section on consent and mental capacity in the CKS topic on Dementia, and the NICE guideline Decision-making and mental capacity.
    • Share information required to provide effective and safe care while respecting confidentiality. Explain the constraints of confidentiality.
    • Explain (with the consent of the person being cared for) how the health condition, disability, or needs of the person they care for are likely to progress so the carer can understand potential changes in their caring role. Be open and honest, including when information is difficult or upsetting.
  • Offer the carer ongoing contact and support and a flexible approach.
    • Recognize the contribution of an advocate or representative (if the carer chooses to have one) and include them in discussions.
  • Offer training to carers (for example structured programmes or one-to-one guidance) to enable them to provide care safely. Ensure training programmes are inclusive and address the needs and preferences of diverse groups.
    • Ensure carers have access to advice, guidance, and training about appropriate use of equipment and adaptations and safe moving and handling techniques, and involve them in assessments for equipment and adaptations.
    • Examples of training the primary care team may consider providing include:
      • Managing medicines.
      • Manual handling courses, to prevent musculoskeletal injuries in carers whose role involves heavy lifting.
      • Tasks such as applying dressings or emptying/changing catheter bags.
  • Provide information and emotional and practical support:
    • To carers when their circumstances change, such as the transition from being a young carer to an adult carer, or if ageing affects their ability to be a carer.
    • To help carers prepare for changes, such as if the person they care for becomes an adult or makes the transition to adult services; moves away from home; has significant health changes; becomes terminally ill; needs end of life care; or dies unexpectedly.
  • Discuss work, if relevant, in relation to their caring role.
    • Encourage carers to have a discussion with their employer about supportive working arrangements to make caring possible (for example flexible hours, fixed hours or shifts, carer's leave).
    • Give information on community services and support that could help them stay in, start, or return to work.
  • Consider practical ways to support carers, including:
    • Offering flexible appointment times (for working carers and the person they care for, examples include carer appointments outside office hours, digital access, and telephone appointments).
    • Offering longer appointments.
    • Referral to local services.
  • Guidance for those who provide unpaid care for friends or family regarding coronavirus infection (COVID-19) is available on the GOV.UK website (www.gov.uk).
  • For more information on how to offer support to carers providing care at the end of life, see End of life care.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Supporting adult carers [NICE, 2020], the NHS England publication An integrated approach to identifying and assessing carer health and wellbeing [NHS England, 2016], the Royal College of General Practitioners report Involving and supporting carers and families [RCGP, 2014], and expert opinion in the review article Assessing and helping carers of older people [Cameron, 2011].

  • Carers' knowledge of the person they care for can be extremely valuable in planning patient care and identifying problems, and engagement with carers is important for good patient care. Involving carers in care planning is likely to lead to better concordance [RCGP, 2014].
  • The NICE guideline committee found qualitative evidence to suggest that carers may lack confidence or feel overwhelmed by their caring role. Evidence suggested this could be improved by training, which can improve carers' skills and lead to a better understanding of the health condition, disability, or needs of the person being cared for. Training programmes can also reduce a carer's feelings of isolation and provide informal emotional support [NICE, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How can I support carers' wellbeing?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Acknowledge that the carer is important in providing care and, to allow that to continue, their health and wellbeing must be maintained.
  • To help carers access healthcare for themselves:
    • Arrange appointments at a time when the carer can leave the person they care for.
    • Consider offering the first appointment to reduce waiting time.
    • Consider consecutive appointments with the person they care for.
    • Address as much as possible during one appointment.
    • Consider offering a home visit if the carer requires medical care but is unable to leave the person they care for.
    • For working carers, offer flexibility when arranging appointments (such as appointments outside office hours, digital access, and telephone appointments).
  • Address a carer's health needs (physical or mental) as soon as possible.
  • Regularly discuss the value of breaks from the caring role and explain the options available.
    • Carers' breaks provide short term care for the person with care needs in their own home or a residential setting on a one-off or regular basis.
  • Provide information and emotional and practical support:
    • To carers when their circumstances change — such as starting or returning to work, acquiring another caring role, changes in financial circumstances or benefits, or personal changes (for example divorce, bereavement, hospital admission).
    • To help carers prepare for changes — such as if the person they care for becomes an adult or moves to adult services; moves away from home; has significant health changes; becomes terminally ill, needs end of life care, or dies unexpectedly.
  • Consider providing carers with psychosocial and psychoeducational support. This should include:
    • Advice on looking after their physical and mental health, and emotional and spiritual wellbeing, including information about emotional support services and psychological therapies and accessing them.
    • Developing personalized strategies.
    • Building carer skills.
  • Be aware that psychosocial and psychoeducational support for carers may be needed at different stages. Ask carers regularly if they feel they would benefit, and if support is needed, arrange the timing to suit the carer's circumstances, also consider factors such as work, family responsibilities, location, accessibility, format, and cultural appropriateness.
  • Consider screening carers for depression at least once a year. For more information, see the CKS topic on Depression.
  • Be alert to the possibility of the carer receiving abuse from the person being cared for, particularly if they have behavioural problems.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Supporting adult carers [NICE, 2020] and also reflect the NHS England publication An integrated approach to identifying and assessing carer health and wellbeing [NHS England, 2016], the Royal College of General Practitioners' report Involving and supporting carers and families [RCGP, 2014], and expert opinion in the review article Assessing and helping carers of older people [Cameron, 2011].

  • By not being alert to and responding to carers' needs, their health and wellbeing, and, by association, that of the people they care for, may be compromised [DHSC, 2018].
  • Low quality evidence suggests that psychosocial and psychoeducational support for carers can help increase knowledge, skills, and confidence in their caring role in addition to improving emotional support, mental wellbeing, and stress management [NICE, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How can I support carers providing care at the end of life?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Make early contact with carers involved in providing end of life care and establish how they can best be supported. Encourage carers to consider how they could be supported by their family, friends, employer, and social networks.
    • Be aware that carers may find accepting help at home difficult when they are providing end of life care. These challenges include supporting carers in their grief and feelings that they are not adequately qualified to deliver what they may perceive to be specialist end of life care. 
  • Involve the same professional care staff, where possible, to provide continuity during end of life care.
  • Regularly offer carers opportunities for discussion and help them understand information regarding the diagnosis and prognosis of the person they care for (with the person's consent).
    • For carers providing end of life care at home, help them access local support services (for example from a hospice).
    • When performing a structured medication review, take into account (where appropriate) the views and understanding of the person and their family or carer(s) about the medicines, and any concerns, questions, or problems that they may have regarding the medicines.
    • Advise carers (or signpost to other agencies) on relevant financial, legal, and logistical issues, where appropriate, when they are preparing for, or following the death of, the person they care for.
  • In terms of advance care planning:
    • Involve carers in advance care planning if the person being cared for gives their consent (if the person being cared for may lack mental capacity, see the NICE guideline on Decision-making and mental capacity for more information).
    • If making an advance care plan involving responsibilities for carers, consider the wishes of carers named in the plan.
    • Confirm carers understand their role in the advance care plan.
    • Share advance care plans with everyone involved in a person's care.
  • Be aware of changes in the information and support needs of carers in planning for their future when the person they care for dies.
  • For more information, see the CKS topic on Palliative care - general issues.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Supporting adult carers [NICE, 2020]. 

  • The quality of the evidence was variable, but it helped the NICE guideline committee ascertain carers' information needs in an end-of-life situation. Strong qualitative evidence suggested that carers value good quality support and care when caring for someone at the end of life at home. A long lasting negative impact on carers can result from unsatisfactory early contact with health and social care services — if carers are not communicated with sensitively, it may add to their distress and make them less likely to seek support from services subsequently [NICE, 2020].
  • A Cochrane systematic review (search date May 2010) [Candy, 2011] identified randomized controlled trials of interventions (including practical and emotional support and/or facilitating coping skills) to support adults caring for a friend or relative in the terminal phase of an illness. Eleven randomized controlled trials were identified (n = 1863). The review concluded that interventions directly supporting the caregiver:
    • Significantly reduced short term psychological distress (low quality evidence from eight trials; standardized mean difference -0.15, 95% CI -0.28 to -0.02).
    • May slightly improve coping skills and quality of life in the short term (low quality evidence from 13 trials; not statistically significant).
    • Were unclear as to which types of support were most beneficial, but interventions that were helpful in terms of psychological distress involved emotional support and information on managing the care of the carer's loved one.
